Pedro and Pablo sit together drinking in Pablo's saloon, where the singer and dancer LuciÃ©rnaga ([[Amalia Aguilar]]) does a fiery dance. One of the bar patron's is so overcome with the moment that he grabs her and kisses her hard. Pedro hops to his feet and decks the offender. LuciÃ©rnaga responds by exclaiming, "Thanks handsome." A short time later, she sends Pedro an invitation, though Bartolo, to join her in her room, which Pedro quickly accepts.
Pedro and Pablo sit together drinking in Pablo's saloon, where the singer and dancer LuciÃ©rnaga ([[Amalia Aguilar]]) does a fiery dance. One of the bar patron's is so overcome with the moment that he grabs her and kisses her hard. Pedro hops to his feet and decks the offender. LuciÃ©rnaga responds by exclaiming, "Thanks handsome." A short time later, she sends Pedro an invitation, though Bartolo, to join her in her room, which Pedro quickly accepts.
â
[[Image:Tucita on horse.jpg|thumb|225px|right|Tucita Arriving at Ranch]]
+
<!-- [[Image:Tucita on horse.jpg|thumb|225px|right|Tucita Arriving at Ranch]]-->
Flor flirts with Pablo shamelessly, leading him to believe that he has a chance with her, if he could only get Pedro out of the way. Flor is also Dona Rosaâs choice for Pedro. She offers Pedro advice as to how to court her. But, Flor continues to coyly sidestep his advances. In desperation, Pedro publicly drops all his other girl friends by singing his farewell to them from horseback in the village square, singing that they will always remain as a "butterfly in his soul". They all take it badly. Finally, after a series of misadventures, Pedro does win over Flor and she agrees to marry him. However, when Pablo hears of this development, he is outraged and swears that he is going to do something about it. LuciÃ©rnaga means "firefly" in Spanish. When Pedro goes to LuciÃ©rnaga to tell her that he cannot see her any more, she tells Pedro that she expects him to marry her. Pedro quickly ends his relationship with her. LuciÃ©rnaga tells him that "fireflies also have stingers" and swears to herself that he is going to pay. LuciÃ©rnaga goes to Pablo, who has just gotten word of Flor's engagement to Pedro, to ask him, as town mayor, to lock up Pedro for the shameful way he had treated her. At which point, he tells him that he has a better idea.

She offers Pedro advice as to how to court her. But, Flor continues to coyly sidestep his advances. In desperation, Pedro publicly drops all his other girl friends by singing his farewell to them from horseback in the village square, singing that they will always remain as a "butterfly in his soul". They all take it badly. Finally, after a series of misadventures, Pedro does win over Flor and she agrees to marry him. However, when Pablo hears of this development, he is outraged and swears that he is going to do something about it. LuciÃ©rnaga means "firefly" in Spanish. When Pedro goes to LuciÃ©rnaga to tell her that he cannot see her any more, she tells Pedro that she expects him to marry her. Pedro quickly ends his relationship with her. LuciÃ©rnaga tells him that "fireflies also have stingers" and swears to herself that he is going to pay. LuciÃ©rnaga goes to Pablo, who has just gotten word of Flor's engagement to Pedro, to ask him, as town mayor, to lock up Pedro for the shameful way he had treated her. At which point, he tells him that he has a better idea.

[[Image:Tucita with photo.jpg|thumb|155px|left|Mama says this is my papa.]]
+
<!-- [[Image:Tucita with photo.jpg|thumb|155px|left|Mama says this is my papa.]] -->
â
[[Image:Rosa stroking Tucita.jpg|thumb|175px|right|You alone are the victim.]]
+
<!-- [[Image:Rosa stroking Tucita.jpg|thumb|175px|right|You alone are the victim.]] -->
That evening, the small child, Tucita shows up on Dona Rosaâs mare at the entrance to her ranch. When Dona Rosa asks Tucita tenderly what she is doing on her mare, Tucita says her mother told her that Dona Rosa was her âgrannyâ. Dona Rosa lovingly takes Tucita from the mare and takes her into the ranch house. She sets her down and gets Tucita to show her a letter she is carrying from Tucitaâs âmotherâ, which says that Tucita is Pedroâs daughter. The letter is signed âyour victimâ. The clincher is that Tucita has a photo of Pedro on a string around her neck. Dona Rosa needs little convincing. She strokes Tucitaâs hair lovingly and tells Tucita that she âalone is the victimâ.
That evening, the small child, Tucita shows up on Dona Rosaâs mare at the entrance to her ranch. When Dona Rosa asks Tucita tenderly what she is doing on her mare, Tucita says her mother told her that Dona Rosa was her âgrannyâ. Dona Rosa lovingly takes Tucita from the mare and takes her into the ranch house. She sets her down and gets Tucita to show her a letter she is carrying from Tucitaâs âmotherâ, which says that Tucita is Pedroâs daughter. The letter is signed âyour victimâ. The clincher is that Tucita has a photo of Pedro on a string around her neck. Dona Rosa needs little convincing. She strokes Tucitaâs hair lovingly and tells Tucita that she âalone is the victimâ.
â
[[Image:Rosa's Surprise.jpg|thumb|210px|left|I have a little present for you precious!]]
+
<!-- [[Image:Rosa's Surprise.jpg|thumb|210px|left|I have a little present for you precious!]] -->
â
[[Image:Tucita and Pedro drunk En.jpg|thumb|190px|right|Lets get this straight!]]
+
<!-- [[Image:Tucita and Pedro drunk En.jpg|thumb|190px|right|Lets get this straight!]] -->
â
At this point, Pedro comes home leading a band and roaring drunk, celebrating his engagement to Flor. Dona Rosa runs off the band and drags Pedro into the house to meet Tucita, telling him that she has a âlittle presentâ for him. Inside, Tucita wants to know why the music stopped. Pedro answers that it is because "Grandmother doesn't want it." Then, he realizes that he is talking to a small child. There is then both a humorous and sadly touching scene in which Tucita immediately takes to Pedro as her father, while Pedro tries to figure out what is going on through a drunken haze. He asks Tucita who she is. Tucita addresses him as âpapaâ. Pedro is very confused by Tucitaâs presence and asks Dona Rosa if she is being serious. She assures him that she is.
+
At this point, Pedro comes home leading a band and roaring drunk, celebrating his engagement to Flor. Dona Rosa runs off the band and drags Pedro into the house to meet Tucita, telling him that she has a âlittle presentâ for him. Inside, Tucita wants to know why the music stopped. Pedro answers that it is because "Grandmother doesn't want it." Then, he realizes that he is talking to a small child. There is then both a humorous and sadly touching scene in which Tucita immediately takes to Pedro as her father, while Pedro tries to figure out what is going on through a drunken haze. He asks Tucita who she is. Tucita addresses him as âpapaâ. Pedro is very confused by Tucitaâs presence and asks Dona Rosa if she is being serious. She assures him that she is. <!--
â
[[Image:Tucita Doesn't know either.jpg|thumb|120px|right|Doesnât know either]]
+
<!-- [[Image:Tucita Doesn't know either.jpg|thumb|120px|right|Doesnât know either]] -->
Dona Rosa and Pedro show Tucita photos of all Pedroâs lady friends, but Tucita does not identify any as her mother. Pedro counts his fingers, considers which lady friends he had seen about the time of Tucitaâs conception and decides that he could not possibly be Tucitaâs father â a conclusion Dona Rosa angrily rejects.
Dona Rosa and Pedro show Tucita photos of all Pedroâs lady friends, but Tucita does not identify any as her mother. Pedro counts his fingers, considers which lady friends he had seen about the time of Tucitaâs conception and decides that he could not possibly be Tucitaâs father â a conclusion Dona Rosa angrily rejects.
â
[[Image:Rosa telling Flor.jpg|thumb|240px|left|Perhaps he doesnât even know himself.]]
+
<!-- [[Image:Rosa telling Flor.jpg|thumb|240px|left|Perhaps he doesnât even know himself.]] -->
Honorably, Dona Rosa goes to Flor right away and tells her about Tucita. Flor asks her who is Tucitaâs mother. Dona Rosa responds that perhaps it is true that Pedro does not even know himself. Flor, deeply hurt, is also quick to believe it and angrily breaks off her engagement with Pedro. Flor goes to Dona Rosa's ranch to see Tucita for herself. She finds Tucita at the well scolding her puppy "Pulgacita" (small flea) for being a womanizer. Throughout the movie Tucita repeats to her puppy a lot of what she hears the adults around her saying as a way of showing the viewers how impresionable she is. Flor lifts Tucita to the well and Tucita shows her the photo of her "father" on the string around her neck. Flor tells her tearfully that she cannot "struggle" against her. Pablo later approaches Flor to try to tell her that he could not possibly be Tucita's father. However, Flor will not listen, which makes Pablo very angry and frustrated. He tells her, "You condemn with outlistening to me" and stomps off.
Honorably, Dona Rosa goes to Flor right away and tells her about Tucita. Flor asks her who is Tucitaâs mother. Dona Rosa responds that perhaps it is true that Pedro does not even know himself. Flor, deeply hurt, is also quick to believe it and angrily breaks off her engagement with Pedro. Flor goes to Dona Rosa's ranch to see Tucita for herself. She finds Tucita at the well scolding her puppy "Pulgacita" (small flea) for being a womanizer. Throughout the movie Tucita repeats to her puppy a lot of what she hears the adults around her saying as a way of showing the viewers how impresionable she is. Flor lifts Tucita to the well and Tucita shows her the photo of her "father" on the string around her neck. Flor tells her tearfully that she cannot "struggle" against her. Pablo later approaches Flor to try to tell her that he could not possibly be Tucita's father. However, Flor will not listen, which makes Pablo very angry and frustrated. He tells her, "You condemn with outlistening to me" and stomps off.
â
[[Image:Pablo and Flor.jpg|thumb|235px|right| If you marry me out of spite, I will accept it.]]
+
<!-- [[Image:Pablo and Flor.jpg|thumb|235px|right| If you marry me out of spite, I will accept it.]] -->
The disreputable Pablo then makes a big play for For, even suggesting that she should marry him out of âspiteâ, as a way to get back at Pedro. He tells her, if that is the reason she marries him, he would accept it. However, in the end and after much struggling with the decision, Flor rejects Pablo and tells him that she is going to marry Pedro anyway, despite everything.
The disreputable Pablo then makes a big play for For, even suggesting that she should marry him out of âspiteâ, as a way to get back at Pedro. He tells her, if that is the reason she marries him, he would accept it. However, in the end and after much struggling with the decision, Flor rejects Pablo and tells him that she is going to marry Pedro anyway, despite everything.
â
[[Image:Infante, Pedro Pablo's idea 13-3-47.jpg|thumb|140px|left|It was Pabloâs Idea]]
+
<!-- [[Image:Infante, Pedro Pablo's idea 13-3-47.jpg|thumb|140px|left|It was Pabloâs Idea]] -->
About this time, Pedro discovers Tucitaâs pretend mother, LuciÃ©rnaga.. Pabloâs henchmen had her under guard to keep her quiet. Pedro frees her and she tells Pedro that Pablo had taken Tucita from an orphanage, had her, pretending to be Tucita's mother, dupe Tucita into thinking she was Pedroâs daughter. She then sent Tucita off to Dona Rosaâs ranch to unwittingly frame Pedro. Pedro confronts Pablo and they fight. Pablo ends up in a lake and starts to drown. Pedro nobly swims out and saves him.
About this time, Pedro discovers Tucitaâs pretend mother, LuciÃ©rnaga.. Pabloâs henchmen had her under guard to keep her quiet. Pedro frees her and she tells Pedro that Pablo had taken Tucita from an orphanage, had her, pretending to be Tucita's mother, dupe Tucita into thinking she was Pedroâs daughter. She then sent Tucita off to Dona Rosaâs ranch to unwittingly frame Pedro. Pedro confronts Pablo and they fight. Pablo ends up in a lake and starts to drown. Pedro nobly swims out and saves him.
In the last scene of the movie, Pedro and Flor come out of the village cathedral after their marriage. However, even just married, Pedro pays too much attention to a passing beauty by exclaiming âVÃ¡lgame Dios (roughly translated "Heaven Help Me!")â. Tucita then also exclaims from the wedding party âVÃ¡lgame Dios!â â showing one and all that despite her non-granddaughter status, she has not lost her place in Dona Rosaâs home or heart. Dona Rosa then drags an unreformed Pedro off by the ear as the movie ends.
